interactions.description: 4 AM - Jett crying. Jillian got up twice to soothe him. I laid there for 5 min while baby cried. She said thanks for the help sarcastically.
interactions.advice: When you hear the baby at night, get up immediately — even if you're exhausted. The 5-minute delay while she handles it alone speaks louder than words. Consider setting up a schedule (alternate nights) so expectations are clear and no one feels abandoned.

interactions.description: Came home from gym, found her reading. Apologized for not helping with Jett at 4am. Offered to take tomorrow morning shift. Took Jones to school. Made breakfast for family.
interactions.advice: This is exactly the right repair sequence: acknowledge the miss, apologize without excuses, and commit to a specific future action. The acts of service (school, breakfast) reinforce the repair. Keep this pattern — repairs build trust when done quickly and genuinely.

interactions.description: Morning school rush. Light situation - set healthy boundary about always language (good). Coffee spill left ring on wood table - got defensive with logic instead of just owning it and cleaning up.
interactions.advice: The boundary-setting was good leadership. But the coffee defense was a missed opportunity — when something matters to her (the table), logic doesn't help. Next time: 'You're right, I'm sorry' + immediately fix it. Save the explaining for later, if ever.

interactions.description: Took initiative to apologize for getting defensive about the coffee. She explained the table is a sore spot. Apologized for that too. Quick repair, no drama.
interactions.advice: Quick repair after defensiveness is gold. You learned something new (the table is a sore spot) which helps you avoid future friction. This builds safety because she sees you can catch yourself and course-correct without being asked.

interactions.description: Jillian made Joshua a sandwich for lunch. Later she shared a story about her job - Joshua was fully engaged, helped her out, made her laugh. She asked him to put Jett down for a nap and he enthusiastically agreed and did it. She looked very happy.
interactions.advice: This is the ideal pattern: receive her care (sandwich), be fully present when she shares, contribute without being asked (enthusiastic with Jett). Her visible happiness is the clearest signal you're in the right zone. More of this energy.

interactions.description: Morning repair attempt after tense night. Started well - said sorry, hugged it out despite eye roll. But second statement (didn't mean to make you feel like you need to change) confused her - wasn't what she was upset about. Revealed real issue: she's bothered by his views on women/submission. He wisely de-escalated with let's drop it.
interactions.advice: The repair instinct was right, the hug worked. But the second statement was solving the wrong problem - always confirm what she's actually upset about before apologizing for something specific. The deeper issue (values on gender roles) won't resolve in a morning hallway chat. That's a longer, calmer conversation for when you're both regulated. Good call de-escalating.

interactions.summary: Discussed different definitions of "submissive." Jillian referenced Webster dictionary definition (which she dislikes). Joshua clarified he means it biblically. Jillian seemed annoyed. Joshua emphasized he doesn't need agreement, just understanding. Conversation ended.
interactions.resolution: neutral - ended without resolution but without escalation
interactions.notes: Values/faith discussion. Important to revisit gently. She heard him but may need processing time.
interactions.follow_up: Give space. Consider a quality time gesture tomorrow without bringing up topic.

interactions.summary: Jillian seemed distant, not engaging in conversation, went to bed early. When Joshua asked how she was feeling, she said she felt a little sick. Not much connection today.
interactions.love_language_opportunity: Acts of service tomorrow (bring her tea/meds if sick, take load off her)
interactions.notes: Follows earlier values conversation. Could be processing that, could genuinely be sick, could be both. Don't assume causation.
interactions.follow_up: Morning: check on her health genuinely. If she's sick, serve. If not, gentle presence without pressure.

interactions.summary: In bed, Jillian asked if Joshua wanted to go to the gym tomorrow. She would stay home with the kids (~75 min). Joshua was already thinking about it - she predicted his want.
interactions.love_language_opportunity: She gave acts of service. Receive it gratefully. Reciprocate quality time after.
interactions.notes: Good sign after earlier distance. She's reaching out in her way. The distance may have been more about feeling sick than the earlier conversation.
interactions.follow_up: Accept the gym offer enthusiastically. Come back energized and present for her.
